content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

This is a low-power view of a large, ulcerated colonic adenocarcinoma. The tumor is fungating and appears to deeply invade through the muscularis propria into the pericolic adipose tissue, suggesting at least a T3 stage. In the pericolic fat at the bottom of the image, there are several discrete, rounded, basophilic structures that are suspicious for lymph nodes.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

The green box is centered on a well-circumscribed, basophilic nodule located in the pericolic fat, separate from the main tumor mass. This morphology is highly characteristic of a lymph node. In a cancer resection case, it is critical to examine every lymph node to check for the presence of metastasis, which determines the N stage. Therefore, I am zooming in to assess this potential lymph node for tumor involvement. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The high-magnification view reveals nests and poorly formed glands of malignant epithelial cells, characterized by large, hyperchromatic, and pleomorphic nuclei. This morphology is consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma. These malignant glands are infiltrating the tissue, which is largely replaced by the tumor and a desmoplastic stromal response. Although residual lymphoid tissue is not prominent in this specific field, the overall context and low-power appearance confirm this is a lymph node almost completely effaced by metastatic carcinoma. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node.
